item.title: Navigating the global ocean of IP‚ÄîA Black entrepreneur‚Äôs perspective on protection and opportunity
item.author: CIPO, Ken Poulin
item.content:encoded: Ken Poulin is an independent trademark agent based in Vancouver. He explains why IP protection should start before and not after market success. As a Black entrepreneur himself, he shares his insights on what it looks like to support underrepresented communities, the role of diversity in Canada's innovation landscape and why educating business owners about the value of IP requires patience, empathy and a personal approach.

item.title: R√©flexions de Thomas Homer-Dixon
item.author: Canada School of PS / √âcole de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / √âcole de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Cette vid√©o met en vedette Thomas Homer-Dixon, fondateur et directeur g√©n√©ral de l'Institut Cascade de l'Universit√© Royal Roads, qui parle de son parcours et de ses travaux portant sur les liens entre le stress environnemental, les conflits et les syst√®mes complexes, tout en appelant √† faire preuve d'une plus grande humilit√©, √† exp√©rimenter et √† planifier √† long terme en vue de s'attaquer √† la polycrise croissante actuelle.
https://www.csps-efpc.gc.ca/video/thomas-homer-dixon-fra.aspx

item.title: Reflections by Thomas Homer-Dixon
item.author: Canada School of PS / √âcole de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / √âcole de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
This video features Thomas Homer-Dixon, Founder and Executive Director of the Cascade Institute at Royal Roads University, who reflects on his life and work examining the links between environmental stress, conflict, and complex systems, while urging greater humility, experimentation, and long-term thinking to address today's growing polycrisis.

item.title: That‚Äôs a wrap on International Development Week 2026!
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: One week. Hundreds of stories. A shared vision for the future. From coast to coast to coast, Canadians joined together to celebrate Prosperity through Partnership.

item.title: Flag Day
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Today we honour the #CanadianFlag and reflect on what the maple leaf represents at home and around the world. üçÅ
As global landscapes shift and new opportunities of cooperation emerge, Canada is reinforcing its role abroad through deeper engagement, strategic partnerships, diversified trade, enhanced security cooperation, and a revitalized diplomatic presence.
Our flag reminds us of the relationships we nurture, the principles we uphold, and the resilience that keeps Canada strong.

item.title: Supporting Workers with Chronic Pain
item.content:encoded: Chronic pain affects 1 in 5 Canadians. It may occur after an injury has healed, or without a known cause. Dr. Andrea Furlan, a pain doctor from the University Health Network at the University of Toronto, joins us to discuss how employers can support workers affected by chronic pain, and how workers can find relief.

item.title: Episode 11: Helping small businesses across the country through the Liaison Officer service
item.source: Taxology ‚Äì The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: Being a small business owner or self-employed individual is a lot of work - meeting clients, fulfilling online orders, developing your business‚Äôs website, and much more. If you‚Äôre acting as the accountant for your business, you also keep your business records up to date for taxes. Did you know the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) has a program to help you, for free? Through the CRA‚Äôs Liaison Officer service, you can get personalized support to help you understand your tax obligations. On this episode, a CRA liaison officer tells us all about the program. You‚Äôll learn what‚Äôs involved in a typical meeting , what help an officer provides, and how to schedule your own personalized visit!

item.title: Women farmers leading into the future
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: 2026 is the International Year of the Woman Farmer.¬† Women are changing the face of farming in Canada. They are highly educated. They‚Äôre working hard. And, while they are having success, they also encounter unique barriers to entry and advancement in the sector. This episode speaks with two women from the Prairies who are at the vanguard of this movement. Learn how they are breaking down barriers. Hear their vision for the future of agriculture in Canada.

item.title: Why are partnerships essential for prosperity?
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Students, professors and practitioners at the University of Ottawa shared a clear message: No country can tackle today‚Äôs global challenges alone.
Whether addressing poverty, inequality or economic growth, strong partnerships are essential. When countries, the private sector and civil society partner, they can create lasting solutions and shared prosperity.
#IDW2026 #Partnerships #InternationalDevelopment

item.title: Why does international development matter to Canada?
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: For International Development Week, we walked the halls of the University of Ottawa to ask students, faculty members and practitioners a question: Why does international development matter to Canada?

item.title: Economic Development Explainer
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Part of our explainer series on international development, this episode looks at how Canada‚Äôs economic development efforts abroad support growth and create benefits for Canadians.
Economic challenges don‚Äôt stop at borders ‚Äî and neither do opportunities. Canada works with partners abroad to reduce poverty, grow economies, and strengthen markets. Learn how global partnerships help drive shared prosperity and a more stable future for all. #EconomicDevelopment #IDW2026

item.title: Bar U Ranch: Grass Into Money
item.content:encoded: For seven decades, the Bar U operated as a corporate ranch, with thousands of cattle fattening up on protein-rich fescue grass in Alberta‚Äôs Rocky Mountain foothills. But that grass has a history of its own, co-evolving on this landscape with a different grazer - the bison - over thousands of years. Through the history of three animals who‚Äôve left their hoofmarks upon the prairie grasslands - bison, cattle and horses - we look at Canada‚Äôs ‚Äúbeef bonanza‚Äù that employed a colourful cast of cowboys, cooks and capitalists, turning grass into money at Bar U Ranch National Historic Site.Special thanks to Jessica Hill.Do you have a suggestion for a new National Historic Person, Site or Event? We‚Äôd love to hear it! Visit https://parks.canada.ca/commemorate for details on how to submit a nomination.

item.title: Want to See How International Volunteering Changes Lives?
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Genevi√®ve spent six months in #Cameroon with the Comp√©tences, Leadership, √âducation program (CL√â), training local guidance counselors.
She returned more skilled, inspired, and ready to make an impact‚Äîat home and abroad!

item.title: Canada‚Äôs Technical Assistance Partnership (TAP) in Jamaica and Dominica
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: For #IDW2026, we spoke with Head of Cooperation Shehryar Sarwar.

item.title: #IDW2026 has officially begun!
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: Join Secretary of State Randeep Sarai and Parliamentary Secretary Yasir Naqvi in celebrating Prosperity through Partnership and the many ways Canadians work with global partners to build a more resilient world.

item.title: International Development Week: Prosperity through Partnership.
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Secretary of State Randeep Sarai unveils the theme of this year‚Äôs International Development Week: Prosperity through Partnership.
Canada and its global partners are building a more sustainable, prosperous future‚Äîtogether.

item.title: Waterton Lakes: Archaeology in a Burned Landscape
item.content:encoded: In August 2017, a lightning strike near Waterton Lakes National Park sparked a devastating wildfire that burned nearly 40% of the park. But in the wake of destruction came a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. We‚Äôll hear from archaeologists and Blackfoot elders about the collaborative archaeology project that‚Äôs deepening our understanding of the lives of Indigenous peoples who have lived and travelled in the Rocky Mountains and foothills for millennia.¬†Do you have a suggestion for a new National Historic Person, Site or Event? We‚Äôd love to hear it! Visit https://parks.canada.ca/commemorate for details on how to submit a nomination.

item.title: Special - Name Change
Fort Lennox: The Accidental Immigrants
item.content:encoded: In 1930s Europe, thousands of Jewish men and teenagers escaped the Nazi regime as refugees, only to be labelled as ‚Äúenemy aliens‚Äù and sent to internment camps across eastern Canada. One of those camps was at Fort Lennox, an old military stronghold on Quebec‚Äôs Ile aux Noix. We‚Äôll hear from one internee, the late Rabbi Erwin Schild, whose story helps illustrate the experience of hundreds of German and Austrian Jews who were imprisoned at Fort Lennox National Historic Site.Oral history recordings of Rabbi Erwin Schild used in this episode:Faye Blum of the Ontario Jewish Archives Teigan Goldsmith of the Ottawa Jewish Archives The Montreal Holocaust Museum The Toronto Holocaust Museum Do you have a suggestion for a new National Historic Person, Site or Event? We‚Äôd love to hear it!

item.title: Canada Trade Mission to Italy
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: Minister Sidhu led 75 Canadian organizations to Italy for a Canada Trade Mission. Why Italy? We asked the Canadian delegates!

item.title: Sit, Stand, Stretch: Preventing Repetitive Strain Injuries at Work
item.content:encoded: Whether work involves prolonged sitting or standing, reducing repetitive strain injuries starts with identifying the hazards and risk factors and improving job design. Here's where workplaces can start.

item.title: Red Bay: Discovering the Basque Whalers of Terra Nova
item.content:encoded: The southern coast of Labrador in the 1500s was the scene of Canada‚Äôs first oil boom. Each summer, Basque crews from Spain and France traversed the Atlantic to hunt whales and render their blubber into a precious commodity: oil that lit the lamps of Europe. It was dangerous, messy‚Ä¶ and profitable. The story was all but lost until the 1970s, when researchers and archaeologists flocked to the tiny community of Red Bay, digging in the gardens and diving in the harbour, to uncover the secrets of Red Bay National Historic Site, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.Special thanks to Joxe Felipe Auzmendi and I√±aki Beraetxe, to Daniel Payne for use of his song and to Javier Vicente for recording assistance. Our condolences to the family of Robert Grenier, who led Parks Canada‚Äôs underwater archaeology work at Red Bay. Robert passed away in January 2026. Do you have a suggestion for a new National Historic Person, Site or Event? We‚Äôd love to hear it!

item.title: ReCollections is back for Season Two
item.content:encoded:
ReCollections, the award-winning history and archaeology podcast from Parks Canada, is back for Season Two. Four new stories from national parks and national historic sites across Canada:
Red Bay: Discovering the Basque Whalers of Terra Nova Fort Lennox: The Accidental Immigrants Bar U Ranch: Grass Into MoneyWaterton Lakes: Archaeology in a Burned Landscape Join us for a journey of national historic significance.

item.title: GDP Explained Without Putting You to Sleep (We Promise!)
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) tells us about the health and size of Canada‚Äôs economy. But for those of us who don‚Äôt own or operate multi-million-dollar companies, why does it matter at all? In this episode, Amanda Sinclair, Assistant director for the National Economic Accounts at Statistics Canada, explains some surprising ways GDP can be useful and why, for certain Canadian households, the numbers don‚Äôt always seem to add up.

item.title: Les principales questions de sant√© et de s√©curit√© de 2025
item.content:encoded: Nous r√©v√©lons les questions en mati√®re de sant√© et de s√©curit√© les plus populaires de l'ann√©e, comme elles ont √©t√© envoy√©es √† notre Ligne d'information sur la s√©curit√©.

item.title: More Than a Transaction: Reimagining Farm Transitions
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: Farm transitions aren‚Äôt simply business deals ‚Äî they‚Äôre deeply human and often emotionally complex. In this episode, we speak with two innovators reimagining how farms change hands and how new farmers find their place. Heather Watson, Executive Director of Farm Management Canada, brings a national view on business planning, succession, and the changing realities of farm ownership. Sara Dent, co-founder of Young Agrarians, is creating new pathways into farming ‚Äî helping aspiring producers find land, mentors, and community.

item.title: New maps to Travel Advice and Advisories on Travel.gc.ca
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: Travel.gc.ca has added maps to 230 Travel Advice and Advisories webpages. Check them out here: https://travel.gc.ca/travelling/advisories

item.title: A Christmas Tree Trivia Showdown
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Think your Christmas tree knowledge is top‚Äënotch? Time to put it to the test!In this holiday special of Eh Sayers, our colleagues face off in a trivia showdown all about Canada‚Äôs Christmas tree industry.Discover which nation first sparked the tradition, how much Canadian Christmas tree farmers earned in 2023, the surprising numbers behind exports and imports, and more festive facts.After listening, you‚Äôll be the go‚Äëto expert on Christmas trees at your holiday party!

item.title: Episode 10: Get help faster with the Canada Revenue Agency‚Äôs digital services
item.source: Taxology ‚Äì The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: Canadians expect and deserve reliable and timely service from the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). We understand that not knowing where to find the information you need can be frustrating. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre dedicated to enhancing our services and simplifying the process for you. On this episode, our expert guest helps you handle your common tax and benefit tasks online. We‚Äôll cover digital services and tools to get help faster, and new improvements that make it easier to manage your whole tax situation. Listen to this episode to learn the fastest way to change your address with the CRA, check the status of a file, chat online with a CRA agent, and much more!

item.title: Top Health and Safety Questions of 2025
item.content:encoded: We reveal the most popular health and safety questions of the year, as sent to our Safety InfoLine service.

item.title: A conversation on powering prosperity in Atlantic Canada
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded: Join Minister Fraser and Don Mills for a conversation on collaboration, innovation, and reshaping our future.

item.title: ACOACanada Live Stream
item.author: ACOACanada

item.title: Canada needs more competition
item.author: Competition Bureau Canada
item.content:encoded:
Canada needs more competition
Could Canada benefit from greater competition? Based on what evidence? What would need to change? Is that what Canadians want? We‚Äôll hear from a senior policy advisor on how competition issues resonate with Canadians based on polling and market research. Matthew Chiasson, Senior Policy Advisor, Competition Bureau Canada

item.title: How can you find out where your tax dollars are spent?
item.author: TBS Canada
item.content:encoded:
The Honourable Shafqat Ali, President of the Treasury Board, provides an overview of the responsability on transparency in government spending.
Video produced by: TBS Communications This video is also available in French: https://youtu.be/u5rAMy9Sp2M
Transcript:
How can you find out where your tax dollars are spent?
Each year, federal departments publish a Departmental Plan outlining what they plan to do and what results they expect to achieve.
After spending a year delivering programs and services to Canadians, they report on what they accomplished in a Departmental Results Report.
Because these programs and services cost money, the government also publishes the Public Accounts of Canada ‚Äî essentially the government‚Äôs balance sheet. It‚Äôs a detailed document listing all government spending for the year. To ensure it is accurate and complete, it is audited by the Auditor General and tabled in Parliament for review.
This allows you ‚Äî and your elected representatives ‚Äî to see how your tax dollars are being used.
For more frequent updates on spending, departments publish Quarterly Financial Reports with a breakdown of spending over the previous three months, and they regularly disclose contracts, travel, and hospitality expenses.
For even more details, you can explore GC InfoBase and the Open Government Portal ‚Äî two online transparency tools that make it easy to dive into the numbers yourself.
The Government of Canada is committed to transparency. It‚Äôs what keeps our democracy strong.

item.title: Screens Replaced Play, and Our Bodies Noticed
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Has Canada become a sedentary nation?¬†Health data have never been more accessible. We have smart watches to count our steps, notifications about our screen times and apps to track our daily diets.¬†Despite the futuristic tech, researchers are growing concerned. And they‚Äôre especially concerned about young Canadians.Today we sat down with Rachel Colley, a senior health researcher at StatCan for a deep dive into Canada‚Äôs obesity, physical activity and screen time trends. And the new data from the Canadian Health Measures survey may surprise you.

item.title: LIVE: Minister Anand‚Äôs press conference
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us LIVE as Minister Anand holds a press conference following a successful #G7FMM!

item.title: R√©duction de l'exposition √† la silice en milieu de travail
item.content:encoded: L'exposition √† la silice, qui peut causer le cancer du poumon, touche les travailleurs de plusieurs secteurs, mais la majorit√© des expositions surviennent dans la construction et le g√©nie civil. Meghan Friesen, des Centres de sant√© des travailleurs (ses) de l'Ontario, se joint √† nous pour discuter de la fa√ßon dont l'Outil de gestion de la silice peut aider √† r√©duire le risque d'exposition et √† prot√©ger les travailleurs.

item.title: Reducing Silica Exposure in the Workplace
item.content:encoded: Exposure to silica can cause serious occupational diseases, including lung cancer. Meghan Friesen of the Occupational Health Clinics for Ontario Workers joins us to discuss how the Silica Control Tool can help reduce the risk of exposure and protect workers.

item.title: How government spending gets approved
item.author: TBS Canada
item.content:encoded:
The Honourable Shafqat Ali, President of the Treasury Board, provides an overview of how government spending is approved.
Video produced by: TBS Communications This video is also available in French: https://youtu.be/Ad9X7xhQbE4
Transcript:
Have you ever wondered how programs like Old Age Security, Child Care, and Dental Care are funded by your government? Let‚Äôs talk about how your tax dollars are used and how services are delivered to Canadians.
Every year, after hearing from Canadians, the Minister of Finance tables the federal budget in the House of Commons. Think of it as the government‚Äôs plan for the year ahead ‚Äî what it wants to do and how it plans to pay for it.
Once the budget is announced and adopted by Parliament, federal departments work hard to turn the government‚Äôs agenda into detailed plans.
Before anything moves forward, the Treasury Board reviews these plans closely. Its role is to ensure that spending is cost-effective, focused on priorities, and delivers real results for Canadians.
After these plans have been reviewed, refined, and approved, the President of the Treasury Board presents the Main Estimates ‚Äî a detailed breakdown of how much money each federal organization is set to receive for the year.
The Estimates are updated up to three times a year through Supplementary Estimates, which reflect changes in priorities and address urgent needs.
Next, Members of Parliament ‚Äî your elected representatives ‚Äî review these spending plans in committee. They ask questions, dig into the details, and make sure everything adds up.
When that is done, all MPs and Senators vote on the Estimates through a supply bill ‚Äî a proposed law that authorizes the spending of government funds.
Once this bill is approved by Parliament, it receives Royal Assent, becoming law through what is known as an Appropriation Act. Only then can departments access the funds they need to deliver programs and services to Canadians.
It‚Äôs a process that may seem complex, but it is built on transparency and accountability. Your government is committed to ensuring your tax dollars are spent wisely to protect the public services that matter most.

item.title: Rodd Charlottetown - Charlottetown, PEI
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
The Rodd family has been a driving force in Atlantic Canada‚Äôs tourism industry for 90 years, and their stunning renovation of Rodd Charlottetown this year shows they have no plans of slowing down.
Transcript The Rodd Charlottetown Hotel has been welcoming guests since 1931. The oldest heritage hotel in Prince Edward Island, the property combines old world charm with modern amenities. With 115 rooms, a restaurant and Victorian-style conference rooms, the full-service hotel is a cornerstone of the downtown core. It's one of four remaining hotels built across the country by Canadian National Railway. In 2024, the historic property began an extensive $10 million renovation. The major project included restoration of the building‚Äôs brick exterior, upgrades to the guest rooms and improvements to energy efficiency. The goal is to preserve the historical integrity of the building while preparing the property for another 100 years. ACOA is proud to support the Rodd Charlottetown Hotel as they honour the past and seize today‚Äôs opportunities.

item.title: The Smart Energy Company - Upper Golden Grove, New Brunswick
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded: The Smart Energy Company is helping farmers cut costs & embrace sustainability. With ACOA‚Äôs support, this Atlantic Canadian small biz is scaling clean energy across Canada.

item.title: Emmerson Packaging ‚Äì Amherst, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Emmerson Packaging is a 3rd-generation family-owned manufacturer and supplier of premium flexible packaging. The company is investing to reduce its carbon footprint and save money, estimating that modern equipment purchased with ACOA support will save $500,000 a year.
Trancript Emmerson Packaging estimates modern equipment purchased with ACOA support will save $500,000 a year.
The 3rd-generation family business has 450 employees and 2 facilities in Amherst, Nova Scotia and Belleville, Ontario.
It manufactures and supplies premium flexible packaging to industries across North America.
As a certified Sustainable Green Printer, Emmerson Packaging makes sustainability a priority.
Its new laminator will decrease energy use by 20%, decrease waste, and create 12 new jobs.
The company is investing to reduce its carbon footprint and save money.

item.title: From Fences to Firewalls: Cyber security in agriculture
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: From phones and computers to automated systems in barns and data collection in harvesters, each piece of technology on a farm is a fantastic tool ‚Äì and a potential weak point. And hackers look for ‚Äì weak points. Just as producers protect livestock and crops from predators, they need to do the same to protect their technology. In this episode, Dr. Ali Dehghantanha, Canada Research Chair in cyber security at the University of Guelph, explains how producers can stay a few simple and innovative steps ahead of the criminals.¬† And Charles-F√©lix Ross, Director General of Quebec‚Äôs UPA, shares what happened when his organization was hit by ransomware and the key lessons learned.¬† Learn more about the Toolkit.

item.title: Psychological Health and Safety in Action with Troy Winters
item.content:encoded: When thinking about workplace health and safety, physical safety is usually top of mind. But for a workplace to be truly healthy and safe, psychological safety is also an essential component. Troy Winters, National Health and Safety Coordinator for CUPE, joins us to discuss what that looks like in practice.

item.title: The Defence Advantage: Built in Atlantic Canada
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic Canada is driving Canada‚Äôs defence industry ‚Äî with innovation, talent, and technology that keep our country secure. From shipbuilding to maintenance and repairs, simulation and training, ground vehicle solutions, cyber resilience, and advanced manufacturing, this region is shaping the future of defence and security. See how Atlantic Canada is: ‚Ä¢ Building world-class solutions in the land, naval and aerospace domains ‚Ä¢ Creating highly skilled jobs and long-term growth ‚Ä¢ Strengthening Canada‚Äôs security at home and abroad #AtlanticCanada #DefenceIndustry #Innovation #AerospaceandDefence #Security #shipbuildingstocks
Transcription: Canada‚Äôs defence future is being built right here in Atlantic Canada. At COVE, where companies fast-track, test, and validate new technology. At NATO‚Äôs Defence Innovation Accelerator for the North Atlantic - known as DIANA ‚Äì where innovators access funding, mentorship, and NATO‚Äôs global innovation network. At PAL Aerospace and IMP Aerospace & Defence - where skilled workers keep our skies secure, coasts monitored, and military aircraft ready-to-fly. At Irving Shipbuilding ‚Äì where Canada‚Äôs next-generation naval and coast guard vessels are being built. And at Atlantic Canada Aerospace & Defence Association member companies across the region, serving both commercial and defence markets globally. Atlantic Canada goes above and beyond to support national defence efforts. And with more defence spending coming, this region is ready to lead. Atlantic Canada‚Äôs defence industry is a national strength. We have the people and the know-how to lead the way, and build a safer world.

item.title: Bridgewater Ready Mix, Bridgewater, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Bridgewater Ready Mix in NS is making concrete more eco-friendly. With support from ACOA, it‚Äôs producing greener concrete and cutting emissions. The company plans to switch to clean energy and reduce CO‚ÇÇ by 40% by 2030.
Transcript Bridgewater Ready Mix in Bridgewater, Nova Scotia takes concrete performance and global warming seriously. The company is committed to the industry‚Äôs plan for net-zero concrete by 2050. With help from ACOA, Bridgewater Ready Mix is increasing green concrete production. Its greening initiatives include many factors. The company is the first in the province to publish Type III Environmental Product Declarations. This provides transparent, objective, and third-party verified data about the environmental performance of its products. The company is an early adopter of limestone cement, which reduces emissions by up to 10% compared to regular cement. And it is making plans to switch to cleaner energy resources to power the plant, mix and transport cement. Greener products, with performance customers count on. Bridgewater Ready Mix aims to reach a 40% CO2 reduction by 2030 on the path to net-zero.

item.title: S5 Ep. 05 - Learning from One Another: Skills, Training, and Workforce Development in Northern Communities
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the Future Skills Podcast, host Jeremy Strachan explores the complex and evolving landscape of skills development and workforce training in Northern and Indigenous communities. Amanda Thompson from The Conference Board of Canada shares insights from the Learning from One Another project, a multi-year initiative examining labour market trends and training strategies across Yukon, Nunavut, and Northern Ontario. We also hear from Kris Mullaly of the Qikiqtani Inuit Association, who discusses the Q-STEP program and Tuttarvik‚Äîcommunity-driven initiatives that are empowering Inuit youth through culturally grounded training and employment supports. Finally, Xina Cowan of EntrepreNorth highlights how entrepreneurship is creating new pathways for economic resilience and self-determination across the North.Amanda Thompson, Lead Research Associate, The Conference Board of CanadaKris Mullaly, Program Manager, Qikiqtani Inuit AssociationXina Cowan, Co-Director, Skills Council of Canada

item.title: Pr√©venir les maladies respiratoires infectieuses au travail
item.content:encoded: Les maladies respiratoires infectieuses peuvent se propager facilement en milieu de travail, et leurs sympt√¥mes varient de l√©gers √† tr√®s graves. Nous discutons des mesures que nous pouvons tous prendre pour nous prot√©ger et prot√©ger les autres pendant la saison du rhume et de la grippe.

item.title: Preventing Respiratory Infectious Diseases in the Workplace
item.content:encoded: Respiratory infectious diseases can spread easily in the workplace, with symptoms ranging from mild to very serious. We discuss the steps we can all take to protect ourselves and others during cold and flu season.

item.title: Ability NB and the Municipality of Grand Lake - New Brunswick
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Accessibility is more than a checklist ‚Äî it‚Äôs a mindset.
Thanks to a partnership between Ability New Brunswick and the Municipality of Grand Lake, supported by ACOA, rural communities are embracing inclusive design and transforming public spaces.
This story shows how thoughtful collaboration can lead to lasting impact ‚Äî and a more accessible future for everyone.
Executive Director of Ability NB, Haley Flaro, says: ‚ÄúThis is our first collaboration with ACOA, and it‚Äôs a shining example of what‚Äôs possible when federal partners work hand-in-hand with communities.‚Äù
Transcript: Alyson:
It all started we were planning to make some renovations to the washroom facilities at the Chipman Heritage Centre.
We knew kinda through residents that they were not easily accessible in a wheelchair or mobility aid.
I ended up speaking with Ability New Brunswick. They let us know that they actually had a free accessibility review that they could do of our buildings.
We learned so much about tactical signage, making sure that our spaces are cane friendly.
It was so much more than just ensuring that people can enter the building.
And from there, we've really started a wonderful collaboration with them that we know will continue past just these buildings.
We have more throughout the municipality, and we are also just really doing our best to promote it to other private businesses in the community.
Haley Flaro:
I just love this collaboration because it‚Äôs a perfect example of community working with community.
And the large tourism that happens, especially in the Grand Lake area drawing more people in to the communities to be able to access important museums, infrastructure, you know, recreation areas.
It‚Äôs really critical., so we‚Äôre really proud of this collaboration.

item.title: PEI Preserve Co. - New Glasgow, Prince Edward Island
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
The PEI Preserve Company is celebrating 40 years of good taste and tradition üéâüçìü´ê A pioneer in the Canadian specialty food industry, the company is embracing innovation and automation so they can spread preserves and joy around the world!
Transcript - Built on old-fashioned values of quality and hospitality, the PEI Preserve Co. has been a pioneer in the Canadian specialty food industry since 1985. Founded by Bruce and Shirley MacNaughton, a humble jar of handmade preserves quickly transformed into an iconic Island business. The operation blossomed to include a river-front restaurant, gift shop, theatre caf√©, 12 acres of gardens, a butterfly house... ...and of course... ...preserves! The preserves are sold worldwide through the company‚Äôs online giftshop, and in three locations across the Island. In 2022, the company was purchased by Adam and Marsha Doiron, who held strong ties to the business and saw its growth potential. The Doirons celebrated the company‚Äôs 40th ‚ÄúJam-iversary‚Äù in 2025, welcoming all who have been a part of the PEI Preserve Co. story. It was a joyful afternoon full of flavour, music and reflection. And special guest Chef Michael Smith opened the 5-millionth jar! PEI Preserve Co. produces up to 100,000 jars per year, and demand continues to grow. So, what‚Äôs next? The Doirons have plans to expand the product line and scale up production to 500,000 jars per year by 2027. The Government of Canada is helping businesses like PEI Preserve Co. become more productive and reach new markets. ACOA is proud to support PEI Preserve Co. as they spread jam and joy around the world!

item.title: Treasury Board at a glance
item.author: TBS Canada
item.content:encoded:
This video is also available in French: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fKK5FauNZek Video produced by: TBS Communications
Transcript: The Treasury Board is a Cabinet committee chaired by the President of the Treasury Board and composed of a Vice-Chair, four or more standing members, and alternate members. Ministers play a corporate role and do not represent their individual portfolios when they take part in meetings. The Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat supports the Board administratively. It provides advice and recommendations. The Treasury Board has two distinct functions known as Part A and Part B. For Part A Ministers will consider proposals‚ÄîTreasury Board submissions‚Äîfrom sponsoring ministers. These submissions seek access to funding and/or authorities, such as the ability to enter into contracts or undertake projects, to advance the government‚Äôs agenda. Treasury Board also approves the ruleset governing financial and project management, contracting, and people and IT management in the government. As the employer, Treasury Board will also be asked to approve collective agreements for the federal public service. Treasury Board considers about 350 proposals per year. For Part B: The Treasury Board also serves as the Governor in Council. It considers regulations and orders-in-council that are meant to protect the health, safety, or security of Canadians and the environment, and support a competitive and innovative economy. Annually, the Treasury Board considers 100 to 200 regulatory proposals. It also considers 200 to 300 non-regulatory orders-in-council including those that authorize Canada to enter into international agreements, or bring legislation into force. Regulations and orders-in-council are typically made public after approval. The Treasury Board usually meets once a week when Parliament is sitting, or more frequently when there are many submissions to consider. Each meeting includes a Part A and a Part B agenda and typically lasts two to three hours. Each Treasury Board submission, along with the Treasury Board Secretariat‚Äôs analysis and recommendation, is typically provided to ministers one week in advance of a Treasury Board meeting. A certain number of items are identified, or ‚Äúflagged‚Äù in advance, because of their scope or profile, and are formally presented to Ministers at the meeting by senior officials from the Secretariat The other items are proposed for approval without discussion; however, during the meeting ministers can ask questions on any item on the agenda. Decisions from Treasury Board are then communicated to departments so they can start implementation or address the Board‚Äôs concerns.

item.title: A Safe and Welcoming Workplace for Newcomers
item.content:encoded: Immigrants contribute significantly to Canada's economy but often face challenges that could impact their health and safety. We speak with Bill Chen of Workplace Safety and Protection Services on how workplaces can create safer and more welcoming environments for newcomers.

item.title: S5 Ep. 04 - Pathways to Self-Employment for Neurodivergent Canadians
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the Future Skills Podcast, host Jeremy Strachan explores how self-employment and entrepreneurship can serve as powerful pathways for neurodivergent Canadians to thrive in the workforce. Jennifer Fane from The Conference Board of Canada discusses her Future Skills Centre-funded research on barriers facing neurodivergent entrepreneurs and the need for tailored support programs; Wanda Deschamps, founder of Liberty Co. and openly autistic entrepreneur, shares her perspective on shifting the narrative from accommodations to strengths and the importance of neuroinclusion in business; and Brad Loiselle, CEO of Skills Council of Canada, reveals how ‚Äúdyslexic thinking‚Äù has fueled his serial entrepreneurship success, from building North America‚Äôs largest wrapping paper business to creating innovative educational platforms.¬†Jennifer Fane, Lead Research Associate, The Conference Board of CanadaWanda Deschamps, Founder and Principal, Liberty Co.Brad Loiselle, CEO and Founder, Skills Council of Canada

item.title: Canadians Just Aren't California Dreamin' These Days
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Calllllll-i-forrrrr-nia... here we come?¬†If you've changed your plans to visit the US recently, you're not alone. Nowadays, Canadians are more likely to be singing along to "Bobcaygeon" than "Sweet Home Alabama."Today, we're sitting down with Jane Lin, of the Tourism Statistics Program at Statistics Canada, to dig into StatCan's tourism data and talk about how travel is different these days.

item.title: Compliance Case Files: Good Business All Around
item.author: Competition Bureau Canada
item.content:encoded:
Disponible en fran√ßais au : https://youtu.be/uhg0EBbsZ2Q
Video on building a competition compliance program. Part of the Compliance Bootcamp, a series of learning modules to help professionals stay on the right side of the law.

item.author: Competition Bureau Canada

item.title: Opening new markets in the Indo-Pacific
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: How do we open new markets in diverse and dynamic countries? What challenges do we face, and what solutions are being used? Chris White, President and CEO of the Canadian Meat Council, and Diedrah Kelly, Executive Director of the Indo-Pacific Agriculture and Agri-Food Office in Manila, share their insights. From building strong trade relationships to promoting Canada‚Äôs trusted brand, this episode explores the work needed to grow Canada‚Äôs presence in one of the world‚Äôs fastest-growing regions.

item.title: S5 Ep. 03: AI in the Workplace and the Skills that Matter Most
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the Future Skills Podcast, host Jeremy Strachan explores the transformative world of Artificial Intelligence and its impact on the Canadian workforce. With insights from experts Noel Baldwin, Stephanie Enders, and Mark Patterson, we hear how Future Skills Centre research is helping us better understand the way AI is reshaping job markets, skills development, and employment strategies. The conversation tackles critical challenges like AI literacy, ethical considerations, and the need for adaptability in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. Discover how workers and businesses can leverage AI to enhance human skills, improve productivity, and navigate the future of work.Noel Baldwin, Executive Director, Future Skills CentreStephanie Enders, Chief Delivery Officer, Alberta Machine Intelligence Institute (Amii)Mark Patterson, Executive Director, Magnet

item.title: A Tariff on Both Your Houses
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Two countries, both alike in dignity,¬†In North America, where we lay our scene,¬†From ancient friendship break to new trade tragedy,¬†Of data on trade and tariffs, what might we glean?¬†Join us as we speak with Guy Gellatly, Chief Economic Advisor, at Statistics Canada, as we explore what‚Äôs been going on with trade with our closest neighbour, what the early numbers suggest about the conflict, and what impact it might have on Canada‚Äôs economy.¬†

item.title: Creating Workplaces Where Everyone Can Thrive
item.content:encoded: Despite legislation designed to protect the rights of two-spirit, trans and non-binary people in Canada, many still face discrimination in their daily lives, including at work or seeking employment. A recent study by Egale Canada seeks to better understand their challenges.

item.title: Episode 9: It pays to grow up: Tax tips when starting to work or starting post-secondary studies
item.source: Taxology ‚Äì The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: Starting your first job or attending university or college? If so, congrats on the big life changes! This episode of Taxology will help you get ready. You may be wondering what your new situation means for your taxes. You may have to do them for the very first time. But don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôre here for you! You‚Äôll learn that not everyone has to pay at tax time. You could actually get more money back with a refund, and you could be eligible for benefits and credits. In this episode, we chat remotely with an expert who helps Canadians learn about their taxes and will share their knowledge with you!

item.title: Porter Talk #6: Porters and the Making of Modern Canada
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: In the final episode of Porter Talk, we dive into how union gains paved the way for a brighter future for Black communities in Canada. This fight for basic human rights significantly contributed to a stronger and more progressive Canada for all. (Episode 6) Transcript

item.title: Porter Talk: Episode 6 Trailer
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: In the final episode of Porter Talk, we dive into how union gains paved the way for a brighter future for Black communities in Canada. This fight for basic human rights significantly contributed to a stronger and more progressive Canada for all. (Episode 6 trailer)TranscriptNarrator Biographies

item.title: Kings County Roadtrip, PEI
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
There‚Äôs never been a better time to hit the road and support Canadian businesses and communities. Hop in and buckle up as we take a trip through Kings County, Prince Edward Island! üöóüó∫Ô∏è
Transcription Let‚Äôs take a trip through Kings County, PEI! This 2-day itinerary is jam packed with authentic sights, flavours and experiences. Follow along! Stop #1 Overnight at 45 Steps Inn in St. Peter‚Äôs Bay Stop #2 Spend a rejuvenating morning at Mysa Nordic Spa Stop #3 Head to the Eastern-most point of PEI to see the East Point Lighthouse Stop #4 Learn about the history of railroad on the Island at the Elmira Railway Museum Stop #5 In the friendly seaside town of Souris, walk the boardwalk and enjoy fresh seafood for dinner Stop #6 Catch a live music show at the Souris Show Hall Stop #7 Drive south and spend the night at Rodd Brudenell River Resort in Cardigan Stop #8 Get out on the water with Tranquility Cove Adventures Stop #9 Pick up a sandwich and fresh local berries at Nabuurs Gardens Stop #10 Step back in time for an afternoon at Roma National Historic Site Stop #11 Grab a coffee and shop around Montague Stop #12 Check out Bogside Brewing Taproom for dinner Stop #13 Drink in the sweeping views at Double Hill Cidery in Caledonia Stop #14 Wrap up your trip with a one-of-a-kind stay at Nellie‚Äôs Landing in Murray Harbour! Thanks for coming along on our road trip through Kings County, PEI! Got wanderlust? Hit the road and support Atlantic Canadian businesses!

item.title: Episode 8: New Country, New Taxes: Info for Newcomers and International Students
item.source: Taxology ‚Äì The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: If you are a newcomer or an international student (welcome!), this episode is for you. On top of learning the Canadian way of life, like managing the snow, ice skating, and how to pronounce poutine, you need to understand Canada‚Äôs tax system. Start here to find out about taxes in Canada and what benefit and credit payments you may be eligible for. Doing your taxes could help you. You may be able to claim education costs or get a tax refund, which is money in your pocket. Tax-free savings plans may also help you save for your future in Canada. Whether you‚Äôre a student starting your first year of post-secondary studies or a newcomer supporting your family this episode of Taxology will boost your tax literacy and give you the confidence to make informed tax decisions.

item.title: Elevating Canada‚Äôs Airline Competition
item.author: Competition Bureau Canada
item.content:encoded:
In 2024, the Bureau launched a market study to examine competition in Canada‚Äôs domestic airline industry and to make recommendations on how it could be improved.
The study ‚Äì Cleared for take-off: Elevating airline competition‚Äîhighlights the barriers that make it hard for new and smaller airlines to enter, grow and compete. It also examines how the lack of competition in the industry impacts Canadians, especially those in northern and remote communities where air transportation may be the only available option for essential services.
Read the report: https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcompetition-bureau.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fhow-we-foster-competition%2Feducation-and-outreach%2Fpublications%2Fcleared-take-elevating-airline-competition%3Futm_campaign%3Dcb-bc-social-media-25-26%26utm_medium%3Dsmo%26utm_source%3Dyt%26utm_content%3Dams-en-250619&data=05%7C02%7Cyves.chartrand%40cb-bc.gc.ca%7Cd2ce0a3bb5bd4c45baa608ddaf27d7b0%7Cb72ac62f06d54cd5824eee92319a4676%7C0%7C0%7C638859307842417914%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJFbXB0eU1hcGkiOnRydWUsIlYiOiIwLjAuMDAwMCIsIlAiOiJXaW4zMiIsIkFOIjoiTWFpbCIsIldUIjoyfQ%3D%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=R8ExA2DOS0vwp3JIzm6z5Hy5dbD5sXmZ9vo6xvgGEtA%3D&reserved=0
Available in French here: https://youtu.be/bzyABiPr8Jc

item.title: Innovative investments: Venture capital funding in agriculture and food
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: Innovators take risks. And they need investors who are willing and informed to help them take the risks.¬† Alison Sunstrum is a pioneering entrepreneur turned investor, now on a mission to fix the gaps she once faced‚Äîmentorship and access to capital‚Äîby investing in exceptional talent and bold ideas in agriculture. Graeme is part of the team at FCC Capital, which is a new effort from Farm Credit Canada to provide what he calls 'patient, and reliable capital' to agri-food and ag-tech companies across the country. Hear how these two and their teams are filling an important funding gap in Canada to help innovation in the ag sector.¬† ¬†

item.title: S5 Ep. 02: Leveraging the Skills of Newcomers
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the , host Jeremy Strachan dives into the critical topic of leveraging the skills of newcomers to Canada and its impact on economic and social success. Joined by Tricia Williams from the Future Skills Centre, Sharon McLennon from the Newfoundland and Labrador Workforce Innovation Centre, and Shamira Madhany from World Education Services, the discussion explores how Future Skills Centre-funded initiatives have shed light on newcomer retention and workforce integration.¬†The episode highlights barriers such as credential recognition, workplace bias, and lack of professional networks while emphasizing solutions like targeted upskilling, wraparound supports, and cultural competency training. With insights into workforce development across Canada, this episode underscores how effectively integrating skilled immigrants is key to addressing labor shortages and boosting economic resilience.Tricia Williams, PhD, Director of Research, Evaluation, and Knowledge Mobilization, Future Skills CentreSharon McLennon, Director, Newfoundland and Labrador Workforce Innovation CentreShamira Madhany, Managing Director and Deputy Executive Director, World Education Services

item.title: L'√©t√© √† l'ext√©rieur, prenez garde √† la chaleur : Conseils pour travailler en toute s√©curit√© dehors
item.content:encoded: √Ä mesure que les journ√©es s'allongent et que les temp√©ratures grimpent, il est agr√©able de passer plus de temps dehors. Cependant, le travail √† l'ext√©rieur durant l'√©t√© comporte des risques particuliers. Dans cet √©pisode, nous examinons ces dangers et proposons des conseils pour que les employeurs et les travailleurs puissent y faire face.

item.title: Temps Up, Heads Up - Working Safely Outdoors
item.content:encoded: As days get longer and temperatures rise, it's great to be able to spend more time outside. But working outdoors in the summer comes with unique hazards. We take a look at what those hazards are, and how employers and workers can prepare.

item.title: Episode 7: Parenting Perks: About the Canada Child Benefit
item.source: Taxology ‚Äì The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: For all you parents out there! Maybe you have a newborn, adopted a child, or have a new parenting situation. If you have a new child in your life, it‚Äôs important to let the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) know since it can affect your taxes and benefits, like the Canada child benefit (CCB) On this episode of Taxology, a CRA expert explains the CCB, clarifies misconceptions and shares how you can apply. We can‚Äôt help you change diapers or build a crib, but we can help you get the benefits and credits you‚Äôre eligible for! So get that baby carrier on, and we will talk while you walk.

item.title: Porter Talk #5: The Women Who Stood With Porters
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we meet some of the strong and devoted women who stood with porters. Without their commitment and persistence, union gains would not have been possible in light of the men‚Äôs absence while working on the rails. (Episode 5) Transcript

item.title: H20: Home to Overseas Conference, 2025 ‚Äì Halifax, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Halifax is buzzing with ocean innovation! The H2O Conference is back‚ÄîCanada‚Äôs biggest ocean tech event and a global hub for marine innovation. Powered by ACOA and hosted by the Ocean Technology Council of Nova Scotia, it all wraps June 12 with Cove Demo Day! #MarineTech #OceanInnovation
Transcript So H2O is a platform that we use to showcase our ocean technology sector. It‚Äôs a way for our companies to come together and showcase their technologies and innovations and work with partners from around the world.
The conference has really grown and scaled over the last ten years.
It started out really as an industry showcase specifically for companies here in Nova Scotia.
But we've really grown it into an international conference with companies from all across Canada and around the world.
Having our international partners here is very important for the H2O conference and for our ocean technology sector as a whole.
We really have worked to turn H2O into an anchor event that's on the calendar of international partners and members of the ocean tech sector around the world.
So for us the ocean technology sector is predominantly driven by export.
So about 80% of our company's revenues come from export.
And with that we need to have partnerships; connections with our international markets.
And the H2O conference is a way to kind of bring those partners in and showcase what we do best here in Atlantic Canada.

item.title: Cruise Canada and New England Symposium, 2025 - Halifax, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Cruise tourism is making a big impact in Atlantic Canada. With support from ACOA, the Atlantic Canada Cruise Association is helping local communities thrive ‚Äî one port at a time. Discover how Halifax and our region are welcoming the world while fueling inclusive economic growth across the East Coast.
Transcript Halifax, Nova Scotia is hosting the Cruise Canada and New England Symposium, where cruise leaders explore new ideas, technology and opportunities. Cruise ships help anchor Atlantic Canada's economy. With ACOA‚Äôs support, the Atlantic Canada Cruise Association champions our region as a top cruise destination, growing an industry that supports small businesses, boosts tourism, and enriches life in coastal communities. And in return we offer more than a stop. We share a story told through heritage, food, music and East Coast spirit. From our harbours to our hospitality, Atlantic Canada welcomes the world.

item.title: On Farm Climate Action in Action
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: Farmers are taking action to protect the environment and strengthen the competitiveness of our agricultural sector. We speak with three producers who are leaders in reducing greenhouse gases, sequestering carbon, and building resilience against climate change. With support from the On-Farm Climate Action Fund (OFCAF), they‚Äôve adopted beneficial management practices (BMPs) that make good business sense. Tune in to hear their insights and advice for fellow producers.

item.title: Episode 6: Explaining the Disability Tax Credit
item.source: Taxology ‚Äì The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: The disability tax credit (DTC) is a non-refundable credit that helps persons with disabilities who have a severe and prolonged physical or mental impairment affecting their daily lives. The credit can also help the family members who support the person with a disability to reduce the amount they may have to pay at tax time. In this episode, we chat with a CRA expert on the DTC, to help you understand the credit and the application process, and to clear up any misconceptions.

item.title: S5 Ep. 01 - What Quality of Work Means in a Changing Labour Market
item.content:encoded: What defines quality of work in today‚Äôs economy? In this episode, host Jeremy Strachan speaks with Laura McDonough from the Future Skills Centre and Dr. Olga Morawczynski from Heal-3 to explore how wages, job security, mental health, and workplace culture impact our experience at work. They discuss how research from the Future Skills Centre has shed insights on the evolving expectations of workers, the role of leadership in job satisfaction, and how benefits and training can shape long-term career well-being. As workplaces continue to change, and as Canada‚Äôs workforce challenges continue to evolve, understanding what job quality means is becoming more important than ever.

item.title: Losing Our Religion? It's Not That Simple
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Is that Canada in the corner? In the spotlight? Are we losing our religion?¬†The census found that 12.6 million people reported no religious affiliation in 2021, more than 1/3 of Canada's population. But is there more to the picture?¬†With guests Simon-Pierre Lacasse, Senior Analyst at StatCan, and Sarah Wilkins-Laflamme, Associate Professor at the University of Waterloo, we're exploring what's driving this trend, whether "no religion" means "no spirituality," and how the story varies from spiritual British Columbia to the cultural Catholicism of Quebec to the freshly painted churches of Atlantic Canada.¬†

item.title: Day of Mourning: Tracey Csordas' Story
item.content:encoded: Threads of Life Ambassador Tracey Csordas' life changed forever the day her brother died in a preventable workplace tragedy. Hear her powerful story.

item.title: Climate Change Impacts on Workplace Health and Safety with Dr. Sarah Henderson
item.content:encoded: Extreme weather events driven by climate change are happening across Canada with increasing frequency. Dr. Sarah Henderson joins us to discuss the potential impacts on workers and how workplaces can build more climate resiliency.

item.title: The Future of Work with Tyler Waye
item.content:encoded: The world around us is changing rapidly ‚Äì and so is the workplace and what motivates us. Work and leadership strategist Tyler Waye joins us to discuss what employers and workers can do to build the thriving workplaces of the future.

item.title: Addressing Inequities in Personal Protective Equipment
item.content:encoded: When personal protective equipment is designed with diverse body types in mind, everyone in the workplace benefits. Dr. Amin Yazdani joins us to discuss how using breakthrough technology can shape the design of more inclusive PPE for workers in Canada.

item.title: Porter Talk: Episode 5 Trailer
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we meet some of the strong and devoted women who stood with porters. Without their commitment and persistence, union gains would not have been possible in light of the men‚Äôs absence while working on the rails. (Episode 5 trailer)TranscriptNarrator Biographies

item.title: What Does It Take to Exit Homelessness?
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: What is it that helps someone transition from homeless to housed? We‚Äôre looking at new analysis of data from the Canadian Housing Survey to explore exactly that. In conversation with Peter Tilley, the CEO of the Ottawa Mission, and Jeff Randle, Chief of the Housing Need Project section at Statistics Canada, we‚Äôre asking why homelessness (and homelessness data!) is more complex than you might think, what factors most often led to regaining housing, and why housing can be challenging to maintain even after it‚Äôs been regained.¬†
